author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Group Tied to Influential Conservative Activist Spent $183 Million in a Year
description: The activist, Leonard Leo, has been instrumental in pushing the federal judiciary to the right. A new tax filing offers a glimpse of the deep pool of money flowing into conservative causes.
content: A deep-pocketed nonprofit organization founded by the conservative activist Leonard A. Leo gave away $182.7 million in a year’s time, a new tax filing shows, demonstrating how aggressively it has worked behind the scenes to prop up other groups and causes on the right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Talbot
title: Manolo Blahnik Turns Over an Old Leaf
description: The fashion house revives a verdant, laurel-inspired ’70s sandal.
content: Born in 1942 to a Spanish mother and a Czech father, Manolo Blahnik grew up playing amid the banana trees of La Palma, one of Spain’s Canary Islands. When he was young, his mother convinced a local cobbler to teach her how to make her own shoes; Blahnik spent hours watching her craft them by hand out of delicate satins and brocades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: What I’m Reading: Summer-Snobs Edition
description: Tales of status, those who have it and those who want it, are on my list.
content: I’ve made a decision that I feel very good about: the theme of my summer fiction reading this year is going to be snobbery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Premier League Crucible Produces Something New: Ideas
description: England has long relied on imported players, imported coaches, imported best practices. Now it’s trying something new for a change.
content: Manchester City had been in possession of the ball for a minute, no more, but to the denizens of the Santiago Bernabéu, it felt like an hour or more. Pep Guardiola’s team moved it backward and forward and then backward again. It switched it from side to side, sometimes via the scenic route, stopping off to admire the view from midfield, and sometimes taking the express.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Chinese Dissident Sentenced to 8 Years After He Tried to Fly to His Dying Wife
description: The activist Yang Maodong said he had only wanted China to “fully realize authentic freedom, democracy, human rights and rule of law.”
content: A court in southern China has sentenced one of the country’s most unyielding human rights activists to eight years in prison for essays he wrote and a website he created, in the ruling Communist Party’s latest warning blow against political dissent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘Yellowjackets’ Season 2, Episode 7 Recap: Punch-Drunk
description: The show is back to having some fun, which was sorely needed after last week’s trauma fest.
content: “Yellowjackets” contains multitudes, and they are all present in the seventh episode of this second season, “Burial.” Did you think this was going to be an entirely somber hour of television dealing with the aftermath of the death of Shauna’s child in the woods? You were mistaken. Yes, there’s some of that. And it’s all very sad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Student Letters to the Editor
description: If you were going to write a letter to the editor of The New York Times this week, what article would you choose to respond to? Why?
content: On April 17, the Opinion section invited high school students to write a letter to the editor in response to a Times news or opinion article that appeared that week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson and John Koblin
title: Striking Writers’ Union Denies Waiver, Imperiling Tony Awards Telecast
description: The Writers Guild of America indicated it would not grant a waiver to allow a live telecast of the Tonys on June 11, threatening one of Broadway’s biggest marketing moments.
content: The union representing thousands of striking television and movie writers denied a waiver that Broadway officials had sought that would have allowed the Tony Awards ceremony to proceed with a live televised broadcast on its scheduled date of June 11, two people briefed on the decision said on Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: New York City Congestion Pricing Plan Could Give Poor Drivers a Discount
description: The tolling program, which would be the first of its kind in the nation, is intended to reduce traffic by charging drivers to enter the busiest parts of Manhattan.
content: As congestion pricing in New York City moves closer to reality, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has finalized a plan to give the city’s neediest drivers a discount and to distribute traffic more evenly by reducing overnight tolls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu, Sapna Maheshwari, Benjamin Mullin and Ryan Mac
title: Elon Musk Appoints Linda Yaccarino Twitter’s New Chief
description: Mr. Musk said Ms. Yaccarino would focus on business operations and he would work on product design and technology at the social media platform.
content: Linda Yaccarino, NBCUniversal’s advertising chief, was preparing to interview Elon Musk, Twitter’s owner, onstage at a conference last month when she received an email from a peer in the advertising industry.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Supreme Upholds California Law on Animal Cruelty
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 12, 2023.
content: “While the Constitution addresses many weighty issues, the type of pork chops California merchants may sell is not on that list.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
title: Ukraine’s Offensive Could Set Stage for Diplomacy With Russia, U.S. Officials Say
description: While exploring endgames, Biden aides say they reject any push for peace talks — including from China — that would freeze the current front lines and Russia’s gains.
content: Ukraine’s planned counteroffensive against Russia has overshadowed talk of a potential negotiated settlement in the conflict, but some U.S. and European officials say the next phase of the war could create momentum for diplomacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Jeffery C. Mays
title: New York Leaders Clash With Mayor Eric Adams Over Migrant Policy
description: During a tense, hourlong call with more than 100 state officials, some said Mr. Adams was not working effectively with them to deal with the thousands of asylum-seekers entering New York.
content: The executive of Orange County thought that he had an understanding: New York City would hold off on sending buses of migrants to the town of Newburgh, N.Y., about 60 miles to the north, until some sort of agreement on the practice was reached. State officials appear to have been on the same page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson, Alan Rappeport and Ivan Penn
title: U.S. Solar Makers Criticize Biden’s Tax Credits as Too Lax on China
description: U.S.-based manufacturers of solar products say rules issued by the Biden administration on Friday will “cement China’s dominance” over the solar industry
content: Biden administration rules released on Friday that will determine which companies and manufacturers can benefit from new solar industry tax credits are being criticized by U.S.-based makers of solar products, who say the guidelines do not go far enough to try to lure manufacturing back from China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Ukrainian Soldiers Risk Their Lives to Keep Weapons From the Black Market
description: They can’t track every shell, but at a time of heightened scrutiny in Washington they know they can ill afford slips with the big ticket items.
content: Rocket launchers, precision-guided missiles and billions of dollars’ worth of other advanced American weapons have given Ukraine a fighting chance against Russia ahead of a counteroffensive. But if even a few of the arms wind up on the black market instead of the battlefield, a Ukrainian lawmaker gloomily predicted, “we’re done.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jean Trinh
title: In Los Angeles, an Indian Chinese Feast Celebrating Female Founders
description: Jing Gao of Fly by Jing and Sana Javeri Kadri of Diaspora Co. hosted a dinner for the women who inspire and support them.
content: In 2018, Jing Gao opened a holiday gift guide in an online newsletter from the organic spice purveyor Diaspora Co. to find a happy surprise. The soon-to-be-launched first product from her new company — the Sichuan chile oil brand Fly by Jing — was among the featured picks from Diaspora’s founder, Sana Javeri Kadri. After Gao got in touch with Kadri over Instagram, the two women quickly went from strangers to confidantes, turning to one another for support and advice as their businesses grew. In the years since, they’ve befriended other female entrepreneurs and, says Gao, leaning on this “founder community is the only way we’ve been able to survive and thrive.” Last spring, they celebrated that mutually actualized success by co-hosting a dinner party for their ever-expanding network. It went so well that they’ve decided to make it a regular event. The most recent gathering took place on a cool April evening at Gao’s 1950s Modernist house in Los Angeles’s Sherman Oaks neighborhood. “It’s a little freestyle,” said Gao of the party that morning, admitting that she hadn’t yet finalized the Indian Chinese menu. “I just went to the market to see what’s fresh and good, so there might be some surprises.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Alex Eaton-Salners provides a puzzle peppered with puns and posers.
content: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Alex Eaton-Salners is a prolific constructor of all kinds of puzzles for The Times. Over the past year his focus has been variety grids. This puzzle is his fourth for Puns and Anagrams since 2021, and in that time we’ve also solved three of his diagramless crosswords. I love solving his puzzles, but even for someone with experience they present challenge after challenge; today’s is par for the course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Little-Noticed Part of G.O.P. Bill Could ‘Make It Impossible to Regulate’
description: House Republicans want every major rule to come up for a vote. That could be a recipe for no regulations at all.
content: Government agencies have proposed dozens of major regulations so far this year. One specifies the kinds of operating cords that can be used on custom window coverings, and another would effectively require carmakers to transition two-thirds of all new passenger cars to electric technology.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Mortal Angst to Domestic Reinvention
description: A selection of recently published books.
content: SKELETONS, by Deborah Landau. (Copper Canyon, paperback, $18.) Landau’s earthy, angsty poems — about sex and mortality and cosmic despair — are insistently quotable, and more fun than they have any right to be. One opens with a line Emily Dickinson might have written, had she been on Twitter: “Sorry not sorry, said death.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Bullying, and Suicide, in High School
description: Readers respond to the suicide of Jack Reid, a Lawrenceville student. Also: Netflix DVDs; the spiraling debt; Republican candidates.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small and Robin Pogrebin
title: The S.I. Newhouse Auction: 16 Paintings, $177.8 Million
description: There were few fireworks at the sale of paintings from Condé Nast’s former chairman. Next week’s sales will test whether the ‘crazy money’ of the past has disappeared.
content: One might expect paintings from the illustrious collection of the late magazine publisher S.I. Newhouse Jr. — by Picasso, de Kooning, Lichtenstein and Bacon, among others — to generate some fireworks in the art market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rob Szypko, Alex Stern, Anita Badejo, Dan Powell, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: Biden’s Radical Option to End the Debt Fight
description: The federal government has perhaps less than a month left before an economically devastating default on its debt.
content: In a high-stakes showdown this week, President Biden and the leaders of congress met face to face in an effort to avoid the United States defaulting on its debt for the first time ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Greenwood
title: Onstage, ‘Brokeback Mountain’ Is Still a Tragedy
description: Much has changed for L.G.B.T.Q. people since Annie Proulx’s short story was published in 1997. But a new theatrical version is a reminder that homophobia is far from over.
content: In 2016, when the theater director Jonathan Butterell was considering a proposal to adapt Annie Proulx’s 1997 short story “Brokeback Mountain” for the stage, he wondered how to translate the prose’s vast landscape and insular emotions into a play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Texas has been taking immigration matters into its own hands.
description: Four C-130 military transport planes towered over the tarmac at the international airport in Austin, Texas, idling with the doors open as the sun rose over a news conference called by the state’s governor, Greg Abbott. As Mr. Abbott began speaking on Monday at a lectern emblazoned with the words “Securing the Border,” about 200 soldiers from the National Guard hustled onto the planes.
content: Four C-130 military transport planes towered over the tarmac at the international airport in Austin, Texas, idling with the doors open as the sun rose over a news conference called by the state’s governor, Greg Abbott. As Mr. Abbott began speaking on Monday at a lectern emblazoned with the words “Securing the Border,” about 200 soldiers from the National Guard hustled onto the planes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson
title: In Xi’s China, Economic Needs May Take a Back Seat to Security
description: Xi Jinping wants to insulate China from perceived threats from the West. He also wants to promote the country as deserving of foreign investment and clout. Can he do both?
content: To revive its sluggish economy, China set out this year to woo foreign investors and stabilize its ties with the West. But these goals are colliding with what China’s leader, Xi Jinping, considers the paramount priority: bolstering national security in a world he sees as full of threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Clarence Thomas Can’t Undermine the Legitimacy of the Supreme Court Fast Enough
description: Democrats are not out to weaken the Supreme Court. But they should be.
content: For Republicans, the investigations into Clarence Thomas and his friendship with Harlan Crow, a Texas billionaire, are just pretexts for an attack on the legitimacy of the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: How Chris Messina Forced Matt Damon to Up His Game in ‘Air’
description: The “actor’s actor” ad-libbed so many funny threats that the movie star couldn’t keep a straight face and resorted to improvisation to keep up.
content: Chris Messina has a hard time admitting that he’s funny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Jeremy Strong to Star in Broadway Revival of ‘An Enemy of the People’
description: The production, with a new script by Amy Herzog and directed by Sam Gold, will begin early next year.
content: “Succession” is ending. So what’s next for Jeremy Strong? He’s returning to Broadway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: James Gunn Always Knew How ‘Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3’ Would End
description: In a spoiler-filled interview, the writer-director discusses the characters’ surprising end points and his relief at bringing the trilogy to a close.
content: When a film is billed as the last installment of a trilogy, fans can’t help but speculate: Who’s going to die? A blockbuster franchise rarely wraps without a few significant casualties, each noble sacrifice underscoring the definitive end to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel
title: Help! My Tour Got Canceled but Travel Insurance Won’t Pay
description: Destruction from Hurricane Ian led a tour operator to cancel a 10-day excursion to Cuba, leaving a woman with a useless $1,500 plane ticket. That’s what travel insurance is for, right? Our columnist dives into the red tape.
content: I had booked a 10-day, $4,424 tour to Cuba for last November, but Hurricane Ian hit the island in late September, knocking out the power grid and causing widespread destruction. The tour organizer canceled the trip, citing health and safety issues, and refunded our money. I had bought my airfare ($1,504) separately, so I assumed my GoReady Pandemic Plus insurance policy would cover it. But when I called the company, an agent told me that because the Havana airport was open, and the hotel I planned to stay in was habitable, it was not worth filing a claim that would surely be denied. If travel insurance doesn’t cover this, what does it cover? Khatiba, Sebastopol, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: More Options to Pay for Medical Care, but Some May Be Costly
description: Consumer experts are warning patients that some offerings charge much higher interest rates than regular credit cards.
content: Patients are increasingly being offered special financing to cover medical treatments that, consumer advocates say, can turn out to be more costly than using conventional credit cards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Nasaw
title: Elon Musk Makes Sense. Yes, Really.
description: Elon Musk’s seemingly erratic behavior is rational if one looks at the true source of his wealth.
content: There is no escaping Elon Musk. Having thrust himself, uninvited and often unwanted, into public consciousness, he is everywhere at once — an omnipresent, Orwellian Big Brother whose smirking visage is inescapable, a jokester, entertainer, troll, provocateur. Commenters lampoon his antics and question his business acumen, even his sanity, but what they don’t recognize — or perhaps what they don’t care to admit to themselves — is that there is a method to his clownish madness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin McCormick
title: My Mother, the Stranger
description: After cutting off all contact with my mother, I tried to let go. Now I’m trying to hold on.
content: I found Soph on an app. I met her at a red-lit wine bar in the West Village. She was exactly as pictured, except warmer, more aglow. Sheepish and charming, with a full laugh that I wanted to swallow for myself, she went in for a hug when I approached her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Hurubie Meko and Nate Schweber
title: Daniel Penny Arraigned on Manslaughter Charge in Jordan Neely’s Killing
description: The Manhattan district attorney’s office charged Mr. Penny with second-degree manslaughter for choking Mr. Neely to death on the subway.
content: Daniel Penny, who while riding the subway last week choked Jordan Neely, a homeless man, to death, was arraigned in Manhattan Criminal Court Friday on a charge of second-degree manslaughter, taking his first formal steps as a defendant in a case that has stunned New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Two Schools of Polling Are Converging: Reflecting on a Tumultuous Decade
description: Should polling change or stay the same? It doesn’t seem a hard call.
content: It’s been nearly a decade since I first attended the annual conference of pollsters, known as AAPOR.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Attack of the Pharma Phantoms
description: Tax avoidance is a drug on the market.
content: On Thursday, Brad Setser of the Council of Foreign Relations — esteemed by cognoscenti for his forensic analyses of balance of payments data — testified to a Senate committee about global tax avoidance by pharmaceutical companies. This issue may not have loomed large on many people’s radar screens, and with everything else going on you may wonder why you should care. But there are at least two reasons you should.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Sophia Lanman and Rowan Niemisto
title: Google’s A.I. Bonanza and Driverless Car Talk With Cruise C.E.O. Kyle Vogt
description: Long-awaited tech like A.I., 3-D telepresence and driverless cars is finally reaching the public.
content: At its biggest event of the year, Google announced an avalanche of A.I. product releases: A.I. in search, A.I. that writes emails and A.I. that generates slides. Is Google pulling ahead in the A.I. arms race?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: A New Round of Middle East Fighting
description: The death of an imprisoned Palestinian militant leader on a hunger strike prompted new skirmishing.
content: For the past three days, a Palestinian group and the Israeli military have been exchanging rocket fire and missile attacks across the Israel-Gaza border. It’s the most intense burst of violence in months. To help you understand what’s going on, my colleague Isabel Kershner, a Times correspondent in Jerusalem, is answering four questions in today’s newsletter. — David Leonhardt
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Claire Fu
title: China Orders Tesla to Recall 1.1 Million Vehicles Over Braking Risks
description: Defects on certain Tesla models could lead drivers to step on the accelerator pedals for longer than necessary, increasing the risk of collisions, China’s market regulator says.
content: China has ordered Tesla, the world’s dominant maker of electric vehicles, to recall 1.1 million vehicles, citing an issue with the acceleration and braking systems of certain models manufactured in China and abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘The Mother’ Review: Are You My Sniper?
description: At the heart of this action-thriller, an expert killer, played by Jennifer Lopez, must rescue her daughter at all costs.
content: A movie called “The Mother” is sure to have a lot of symbolism and this action-thriller, starring Jennifer Lopez as a trained killer who must protect the daughter she gave up, has plenty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: Labors of Love
description: In new novels by the National Book Award finalists Gary D. Schmidt and Brandon Hobson, adolescent boys navigating parental loss find strength in ancient mythology.
content: Two very different new novels for young readers bear striking similarities. Both feature boys narrating their own tales of taking on heroic tasks as they work through the emotional devastation of losing parents. (These quests echo ancient myths — Greek in one case, Cherokee in the other.) Both involve the serious challenge of surviving middle school. And both spring from the imaginations of National Book Award finalists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukraine’s Advances Near Bakhmut Expose Rifts in Russian Forces
description: Russia’s pro-war bloggers were quick to claim that Ukraine’s long-anticipated counteroffensive had begun, but Ukrainian officials downplayed the advances.
content: The Ukrainian Army is advancing in attacks near the eastern city of Bakhmut, Ukrainian commanders said on Friday, in fighting that has shifted the front line only slightly but is exposing fissures, confusion and alarm among Russia’s forces in the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: The Los Angeles Opera, Post-Plácido Domingo
description: The star tenor played a central role at the company from the start. Since his ouster, it has worked to define itself on its own terms.
content: LOS ANGELES — When the tenor Russell Thomas appeared at the Los Angeles Opera in 2017, Plácido Domingo, the company’s general director, asked him to return one day to sing the title role in Verdi’s “Otello.” It was a notable invitation coming from Domingo, the leading Otello of his day, who sang the role in 1986 at the very first performance of the Los Angeles company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: It’s Called Eurovision. So Why Is Australia Part of It?
description: Australia has been one of the event’s biggest markets outside Europe. Since 2015, it has been a contestant, but that may end after this year’s final.
content: The confluence of outlandish costumes, soulful folk ballads and an ode to the great American writer Edgar Allan Poe can only mean that Eurovision, the world’s largest, gaudiest and, perhaps, most eccentric song competition is gracing our screens again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael E. Webber
title: Will Texas Blow Up Its Energy Miracle to Bolster Fossil Fuels?
description: Legislators are moving to erect barriers to clean energy development while providing incentives for fossil fuels.
content: Because the Texas energy system is so large and central to the American economy, we all have a shared stake in its energy success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: What Do You Call 2,326 Kyles in One Place? A World Record.
description: Kyle, Texas, is hosting a fair this month to try to break the world record for the largest gathering of people with the same first name.
content: Is your name Kyle?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: What to Know About the New Treatment for Hot Flashes
description: Veozah, a nonhormonal drug, is effective against a signature symptom of menopause.
content: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new nonhormonal oral drug Friday, under the brand name Veozah, designed to treat menopausal hot flashes. The drug provides women with a “safe and effective treatment option,” Dr. Janet Maynard, director of the F.D.A. Office of Rare Diseases, Pediatrics, Urologic and Reproductive Medicine said in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 12, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, May 12, 2023.
content: An article on Thursday about President Biden’s plan to host Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India on a state visit next month misstated the status of the case against the Indian opposition leader Rahul Gandhi. Mr. Gandhi is charged with defamation, but has not been jailed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Miller
title: How a Solo Gig Can Give You a Stronger Retirement
description: Becoming a solo entrepreneur in the years after leaving an employer can give your Social Security benefit and savings a boost. Here’s what to know.
content: Russ Eanes was burning out at his job, and he had just hit 60 — but he wasn’t ready to retire. A former minister in the Mennonite church, he had worked for a decade as an executive at a religious book publisher, but found himself in the unhappy role of helping to shrink the organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy, Judson Jones and McKenna Oxenden
title: Severe Storms Strike Plains After a Night of Tornado Reports
description: More severe weather arrived a day after tornadoes were reported across five states, from Colorado to Louisiana, on Thursday.
content: Severe weather, including high winds and very large hail, was pummeling the Southern Plains on Friday evening, a day after tornadoes were reported across five states, forecasters said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Conservative Media Has an Audience Problem
description: Why right-wing journalism is a prisoner of TV.
content: In last week’s newsletter, I wrote about the divergent intellectual climates in journalism and academia, but mostly left conservative media out of the discussion. Now we have a new YouGov survey on public trust in media that provides an opening to talk about the climate on the right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Struggle to Explain the ‘Gender Well-Being Gap’
description: Women report more depression and anxiety than men, but greater life satisfaction — and we don’t know why.
content: Just in time for Mother’s Day comes new research analyzing surveys that show that women around the world are more likely than men to say they are depressed, lonely, anxious, downhearted, tense, frustrated, sad and experiencing restless sleep. In other words, being a woman — mother or not — is no picnic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louise Rafkin
title: After a Yearlong Dating Hiatus, (Cautiously) Embracing Something New
description: Friendship came naturally to Ande Flower and Veronica Savage, but romance was more difficult to foresee. However, they persisted — all the way to the ‘yacht rock’ altar.
content: For Ande Flower, the first year of the pandemic coincided conveniently with a personal commitment to staying single. Mr. Flower began transitioning from female to male in 2018, following a move from Seattle to Pacific Grove, Calif., for a new job. At the turn of 2020, he began a new chapter of his life publicly living as a man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: How Liverpool Put on a Song Contest for Ukraine
description: This year’s event would be “Ukraine’s party,” a broadcasting official said. It just happens to be taking place in Britain.
content: When Ukraine won last year’s Eurovision Song Contest, it gained the right to hold this year’s event. And despite Russia’s invasion, it insisted it would do it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy and Michael Levenson
title: Woman With ‘Doomsday’ Beliefs Found Guilty in Children’s Deaths
description: Lori Vallow Daybell was convicted in Idaho of murder in the deaths of two of her children and of conspiring to murder her husband’s previous wife. Prosecutors said she was driven by her extreme religious beliefs.
content: A jury in Idaho found Lori Vallow Daybell guilty on Friday of murdering two of her children and of conspiring to murder her husband’s former wife in a case that drew widespread attention for what prosecutors described as her “doomsday” religious beliefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Mike Pride, Who Proved a Regional Newspaper Could Work, Dies at 76
description: For 25 years he was editor of The Concord Monitor, an award-winning go-to source every four years for national reporters covering the New Hampshire presidential primary.
content: Mike Pride, who transformed the New Hampshire newspaper The Concord Monitor into a prizewinning paragon of regional journalism, mentoring generations of reporters and editors, defying the trope about the dying small-town newspaper and exerting an outsize impact on his profession, died on April 24 in a hospice in Palm Harbor, Fla. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: White House Taps Two Economists for Top Fed Jobs
description: President Biden announced his plan to nominate Adriana Kugler, an official at the World Bank, for a Fed governor job, while elevating Philip Jefferson to the role of vice chair.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Friday said he would nominate Adriana Kugler for a seat on the Federal Reserve Board and would elevate Philip Jefferson, a current governor, as vice chair of the central bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Dan Snyder to Proceed With Sale of Washington Commanders to Josh Harris
description: The embattled N.F.L. owner had reached a $6 billion deal in April with a group led by Harris but continued to seek higher bids. Other league owners are expected to review the sale at the end of this month.
content: Dan and Tanya Snyder agreed on Friday to sell the Washington Commanders to an investment group led by Josh Harris, leaving the N.F.L. to sign off on the proposed $6 billion sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: The timing of Ukraine’s counteroffensive.
content: Volodymyr Zelensky, the president of Ukraine, said yesterday that it needed more time to begin a counteroffensive against Russia because Ukraine’s forces are still waiting for military equipment promised by the West. “We’d lose a lot of people,” he said. “I think that’s unacceptable. So we need to wait. We still need a bit more time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: All the Asparagus
description: Spring’s characteristic spears shine in a spinach and leek soup, a salad with coconut and green beans and a filling mushroom grain bowl.
content: Good morning. Is there an American cuisine? My friend Ned says there is: It’s the food Americans eat. That’s kung pao chicken and spaghetti with meat sauce. It’s fried chicken, cheese enchiladas, latkes and blueberry muffins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: ‘Mommunes’: Mothers Are Living Single Together
description: Women are joining forces under one roof, using the age-old power of sisterhood to split the household bills and raise their children.
content: First, Kristin Batykefer lost her marketing job when there was a management change. Then her marriage fell apart, and she suddenly found herself with no income and nowhere to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Alberto Urrea
title: My Mother Returned From World War II a Changed Woman
description: In her World War II photographs and those of her friends, my mother is laughing and bright-eyed in every single one. I almost don’t recognize her.
content: At the end of World War II, my mother, Phyllis McLaughlin, was sent home after weeks in a battlefront hospital tent, her legs wired and sutured together. She had tumbled off a mountain in the Bavarian Alps in a Jeep accident that nearly killed her. Her scars were familiar to me, born 10 years later, but I did not understand that the wounds from her service would never heal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: unperturbed
description: This word has appeared in 14 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word unperturbed has appeared in 14 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 13 in “The State of Kate” by Rhonda Garelick:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and James Hill
title: Olympic Swimming in the Seine? How Paris Is Remaking a River.
description: Organizers of the 2024 Summer Games promised a waterway clean enough for Olympic swimmers and then Parisians to swim in. The job was bigger than anyone knew.
content: PARIS — An electric delivery boat pushed up the Seine, past the former palaces and elegant museums and under the low-slung stone and metal bridges before turning at the Eiffel Tower and gliding to the riverbank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: ‘Crater’ Review: A Rocking Road Trip
description: This Disney film is surprisingly nimble at incorporating an emotional core into its sci-fi adventure.
content: You wouldn’t necessarily expect a lightly dystopian undertone concerning the oppressive state of labor in a family-friendly science-fiction Disney film (released during the writers’ strike, no less), but “Crater” manages just that while maintaining the lighthearted fun of a children’s adventure.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When Books Go Viral
description: Featuring Twitter and the Swifties.
content: Today’s newsletter is a tale of two very different book sagas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Flush With Federal Money, Strings Attached, a Deep South Factory Votes to Unionize
description: Friday’s victory by the United Steelworkers at a factory building electric school buses was a test for Democratic hopes that clean-energy funding from Washington could bolster organized labor.
content: Workers at a rural Georgia factory that builds electric school buses under generous federal subsidies voted to unionize on Friday, handing organized labor and Democrats a surprise victory in their hopes to turn huge new infusions of money from Washington into a union beachhead in the Deep South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Want to Make Your Mom Happy? Tell Her She Was Right.
description: It may be the perfect Mother’s Day gift.
content: My mother was right about so many things: You can love a person without loving their behavior. You should never criticize someone else’s kid. My old boyfriend who couldn’t make eye contact was hiding a lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan O'Callaghan
title: With 62 Newly Discovered Moons, Saturn Knocks Jupiter Off Its Pedestal
description: If all the objects are recognized by scientific authorities, the ringed giant world will have 145 moons in its orbit.
content: In the red corner, Jupiter, the largest planet orbiting our sun, which shaped our solar system with its gravitational bulk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: U.S. Ends Last Covid Travel Barrier, Vaccine Mandate for Foreign Arrivals
description: International travelers entering the country are no longer required to be vaccinated, removing the last of the restrictions on travel put in place beginning in 2020.
content: International passengers traveling to the United States no longer have to show proof of vaccination against Covid as of midnight Thursday, when the coronavirus health emergency officially ended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Hypnotic’ Review: A Twisty Thriller Sends Ben Affleck on the Run
description: Alice Braga plays a psychic and Affleck a cop in this action-packed Robert Rodriguez picture that gets a little overly ambitious.
content: Seasoned moviegoers complain these days that blockbuster franchises and formulaic streaming fare have all but squeezed out the midbudget character-driven drama. But it’s worse than that. The state of the biz isn’t doing wonders for tight, low-budget, midlength action thrillers with sci-fi or supernatural plot hooks, either. So on learning that, after almost a decade working primarily in television or on movies with a strong Y.A. slant, the dynamic director Robert Rodriguez has a Ben Affleck-led suspense thriller called “Hypnotic” in theaters, even a casual genre hound might cock an intrigued eyebrow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Fighting Between Israel and Islamic Jihad: Where Things Stand
description: Exchanges of fire continued on Friday despite overnight mediation efforts for a cease-fire.
content: Fierce cross-border fighting resumed on Friday between Israel and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad militant group in Gaza, with the Israeli military killing another of the group’s top commanders in a missile strike on a residential building after rockets fired out of Gaza reached as far as the hills around Jerusalem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Chokehold Killing Fuels Scrutiny of Police’s Growing Role in Subways
description: Jordan Neely’s death has renewed debate over the New York City mayor’s strategy of flooding platforms with police officers to improve safety.
content: The push to saturate New York City’s subway with police officers last year was supposed to make the system feel safer after a sequence of shocking crimes rattled commuters and discouraged many from using public transit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: The Biggest Explosion in the Cosmos Just Keeps Going
description: For three years, telescopes have monitored “one of the most luminous” events ever: a supermassive black hole consuming a gigantic cloud of interstellar gas.
content: It’s a dog-eat-dog cosmos. Not two weeks ago, on May 3, astronomers reported observing a star that was in the process of swallowing one of its own planets. Just two days earlier, another team had described black holes that were ripping stars apart and consuming them in a process known as tidal disruption event, or T.D.E.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Calls to Investigate Short Sellers Intensify as Bank Crisis Deepens
description: Jamie Dimon is the latest to urge action against the traders who have targeted the regional lenders and made huge profits.
content: As the shares of another regional bank tumbled on Thursday, Jamie Dimon, the JPMorgan Chase chief, ratcheted up the pressure on regulators to “finish” the crisis at small and midsize lenders, and joined the chorus calling for an investigation into short sellers as part of any solution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: A Guide to Eurovision 2023
description: The international song contest — which has helped launch acts like Abba and Maneskin — takes place in England this year. Here’s what to expect from this edition.
content: The Eurovision Song Contest has been an annual fixture in the global pop calendar since 1956 — with the exception of 2020, when the competition took an enforced Covid-19 gap year — and this month, the competition takes place in Liverpool, England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Build in the Suburbs, Solve the Housing Crisis
description: An ambitious plan to bring high-density housing to New York’s commuter towns was met with that rarest of things: bipartisan resistance.
content: Earlier this week, the governor of Washington, Jay Inslee, signed a law that would prevent cities and towns across the state from limiting themselves exclusively to the construction of single-family homes. Washington, like the rest of the country, faces an acute housing shortage, driven in part by restrictive zoning codes that have long perpetuated racial and economic inequity. The new legislation would allow neighborhoods to meet shifting demographic realities, in the process delivering a greater social good — a couple living in a Tudor revival on a street full of old-growth trees, for example, might find themselves now next door to a triplex with a single doctor in one unit, a young couple with an infant in another, a widowed civil servant in a third.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Havrilesky
title: There Are No Universal Salves
description: A mother finds herself spiritually out of stock at the Glossier flagship store in New York City.
content: My children and I were visiting New York City’s most important landmarks, so naturally we began our journey at the Glossier flagship store in SoHo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: C.I.A. Says It Will Overhaul Handling of Sexual Assault Allegations
description: Congress had begun investigating whether the agency was making it too difficult for women to file complaints of harassment or assault against other C.I.A. officers.
content: WASHINGTON — The Central Intelligence Agency announced on Thursday that it would overhaul its process for handling sexual assault and harassment accusations in the wake of allegations that the agency had discouraged people from filing formal complaints or had mishandled them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: How She ‘Manifested’ Marrying Her Secret Crush
description: Allison Flynn was immediately drawn to Jeffrey Hood after meeting him on the job in Charleston, S.C., more than six years ago. “I kept telling people, ‘I’m going to marry him,’” she said.
content: Allison Alyssa Flynn had a secret crush on Jeffrey Charles Hood from the moment she met him — a secret from Mr. Hood, that is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Dog Reporting Is No Fluffy Subject
description: Why hold back when covering the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show? Write a profile of a retired Samoyed.
content: As we watched the final round of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show last year, my New York Times colleagues and I were particularly taken by one contestant: Striker the Samoyed, a blindingly white cloud of canine fluff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: How the Last Writers’ Strike Changed Things Onscreen
description: The impact included promising shows that lost their audiences, films rushed into production with flimsy scripts and turbocharging reality programming.
content: The 2007 writers’ strike couldn’t have come at a worse time for the screenwriter Zack Stentz. After three years of being unemployed, Mr. Stentz was happily ensconced in a new job as an executive story editor on Fox’s “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles.” He was working with a high-caliber group of writers on a show he described as “dark, thoughtful and weird.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ismail Muhammad
title: The Most Disturbing Thing About Jordan Neely’s Killing
description: It was all so calm and unhurried. Sometimes, somehow, the fear of violence shakes people more than violence itself.
content: At the opening of the video, the audio is strangely muffled. Juan Alberto Vázquez, the freelance journalist who captured the footage, begins recording from outside the train car where Daniel Penny has a 30-year-old homeless man named Jordan Neely in a chokehold. A couple of other passengers help restrain Neely, making sure he cannot wrestle free. Neely opens his mouth, but all we can hear is people chattering over the electric whir of machinery, the sounds of shoes squeaking on the station’s floors, the squeal of other trains arriving and taking their leave — all the engulfing, familiar white noise of a New York subway station. Despite the violent death we know is coming, the sounds are those of a stultifying normalcy. A voice rises above the hum, calling for the police via a loudspeaker, but there is no particular urgency in that call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: With ‘Monica,’ Trace Lysette Is Ready for More
description: The transgender actress plays the title role in a new drama that, she says, is “not just a trans story, it’s a family story.”
content: Trace Lysette has no children but she is a mom. Or was: For about a decade she reigned as mother of the House of Mizrahi, a legendary house, as the voguers will tell you, in New York’s ballroom scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Tucker Carlson on Twitter Could Work Awfully Well
description: Could the talking head continue to shape the discourse — or the meaning of “show”?
content: Tucker Carlson is taking his talents to Elon Musk’s Twitter. We should have seen it coming. The pairing, the peanut butter and chocolate of right-wing, edgelord provocation, makes perfect sense: Two great trolls that could troll great together, heaven help us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Wendy Sherman, U.S. Diplomat Known for ‘Hard Conversations in Hard Places,’ to Retire
description: She began her first diplomatic job 30 years ago, led talks on the Iran nuclear deal and grapples with China and Russia. She is also the first woman to be deputy secretary of state.
content: After Russia had amassed 100,000 troops by Ukraine’s borders in what appeared to be preparations for an invasion, the Biden administration sent one of its top diplomats to talk with her Russian counterpart to try to dissuade Moscow from a full-scale war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Covid Cautions Continue for Some, Even as Federal Emergency Ends
description: While mandates and lockdowns are long gone, the virus isn’t and, for some Americans, neither are masks.
content: For millions of Americans, the Covid-19 emergency, that disorienting stretch of lockdowns, mandates, free-floating anxiety and exhaustion came to a muted end sometime during the past couple of years, brought about by vaccines and antiviral drugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Taylor
title: Three New Story Collections Make Place a Protagonist
description: From Turkey to Mexico to San Antonio, Tex., the settings of these tales are as vivid as their characters.
content: The Turkish president Recep Erdogan looms large in Kenan Orhan’s I AM MY COUNTRY: And Other Stories (Random House, 227 pp., $27), a powerful and provocative debut collection with a vivid sense of place. “The Stray of Ankara” is about a woman training a dog to act as a suicide bomber to assassinate the authoritarian ruler before he can do further damage to the country’s government, environment and civil society. In “Soma,” Erdogan visits a mining town after a devastating collapse and attempts to console the crowd by telling them that the price of coal production has dropped drastically since the industry was privatized. (They respond by chanting, “Murderer Erdogan.”) In “The Beyoglu Municipality Waste Management Orchestra,” successive waves of anti-Western sentiment and government repression cause people to purge their homes of contraband. A garbagewoman hoards discarded items she finds in the course of her collections: musical scores, musical instruments, eventually musicians. She gathers enough of each to make good on the story’s title and its magical realist conceit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Backlogged Courts and Years of Delays Await Many Migrants
description: A severe shortage of immigration judges has led to long delays for asylum cases. The backlog is expected to grow now that pandemic-era border restrictions have been lifted.
content: President Biden’s attempt to deal efficiently with a new surge of migration following the end of Title 42 pandemic restrictions has focused new attention on a severe shortage of judges, the result of longstanding neglect that has overwhelmed the immigration court system with a backlog of more than two million cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘The Beautiful Lady’ Review: A Cabaret for the New Order
description: Artists and dreamers sing of revolution in a musical set on the cusp of the birth of the Soviet Union.
content: A few minutes into “The Beautiful Lady,” you might find yourself thinking the show owes a little something to “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812”: After all, here are, again, a bunch of exalted Russians in a cabaret, singing of life, loss, hope and love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: ‘A Bit Spooky’: The New Shark Species With Bright, White Eyes
description: A newly discovered species of demon catshark is found in the deep waters off Australia.
content: What has long, bright white eyes, swims along the deep waters off Australia and attaches its eggs to coral?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: A New Hope for Manhattan’s Chino Latino Restaurants: TikTok
description: These fading institutions, where lo mein and mofongo are served side by side, have found a new customer base.
content: During a recent weekday lunch rush at his restaurant on the Upper West Side, Richard Lam hurried around the dining room fielding orders from his regulars for dishes like wonton soup, General Tso’s chicken and fried rice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Behind the New Indictments of El Chapo’s Sons, Rivalry Seethed Between Agencies
description: When sweeping charges against the Chapitos were announced last month, the Justice Department presented a unified front. It was another story behind the scenes.
content: Last May, a team of federal agents chasing the sons of Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the Mexican drug lord known as El Chapo, caught a break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: This week’s picks feature A.I. kids, comic time loops and killer robots.
content: Franklin Ritch’s feature starts off like a taut thriller: a couple of agents, Deena and Amos (Sinda Nichols and David Girard), are grilling Gareth (Ritch), who has created a digital little girl to bait and catch online predators. Cherry (Tatum Matthews) has the appearance of an 11-year-old and her software is so sophisticated that, as Gareth puts it, she is almost completely “on autopilot.” Her behavior is so humanlike that a troubled Amos wonders if Cherry has feelings, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Gwyther
title: The Business Nightmare of Navigating Geopolitics
description: The rise of populism is testing corporations’ relationship with government, but it’s hard for C.E.O.s to engage without getting clobbered.
content: If one considers the extraordinary backlash that has hit Anheuser-Busch and its Bud Light beer brand over a marketing campaign with a transgender influencer, imagine the perils if a corporation puts its head above the parapet to express opinions of geopolitical importance. How business leaders should engage with politics is a vexed question, especially in these febrile times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: China will send an envoy to Russia and Ukraine in a quest for peace talks.
description: Li Hui, China’s special representative for Eurasian affairs, is expected to begin his trip on Monday.
content: A Chinese government envoy will visit Ukraine and Russia next week in an attempt to help negotiate an end to the war, a Chinese government spokesman said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Eileen Sullivan
title: Federal Judge Says Border Patrol Can’t Forgo Release Notices to Ease Backups
description: The order does not affect the expiration of the pandemic-era Title 42 immigration restrictions, according to an expert. But it could complicate efforts to manage how many migrants cross into the United States.
content: A federal judge in Florida issued an order late Thursday directing the U.S. Border Patrol not to release any migrants into the United States without issuing them formal notices to appear in immigration court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: How to Treat Postpartum Depression
description: Mental health issues are the leading cause of maternal mortality. Group therapy, S.S.R.I.s and a new medication can help.
content: In recent years, mental health struggles have become the leading cause of maternal mortality in the United States, primarily due to suicides and drug overdoses. It is estimated that one in eight new moms experience postpartum depression, and some research has suggested that the prevalence climbed to as high as one in three during the early days of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Anxiety but Not Chaos at the Border
description: Also, an election to watch in Turkey. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: Today marked the first day in more than three years that the Biden administration was unable to use pandemic-era restrictions known as Title 42 to expel migrants looking to cross into the U.S. As anticipated, the end of Title 42 spurred thousands of migrants to cross into the country, putting significant pressure on border facilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel and Reid J. Epstein
title: Immigration Politics Return to the Forefront as the 2024 Race Picks Up Pace
description: Donald J. Trump rode border security to the presidency in 2016. Republicans hope the issue will be at the center of the debate again.
content: Border security, the issue that largely defined Donald J. Trump’s victorious 2016 campaign, is back on the national agenda, a potential boost for Mr. Trump — and, for President Biden, a headache with no simple remedy in either policy or politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: At ‘Tartuffe’ in the Park, Hypocrisy Is No Picnic
description: The 17th-century play, staged by the theater company Molière in the Park, skewers those who preach morality yet practice anything but.
content: I like to think that Molière, the great French playwright who died in 1673, would have really enjoyed the flagrant hypocrisy of our current political moment. Each month seems to bring new duplicities and new scandals, lies big and small — the résumés embroidered like Rococo tapestries, the lawmakers endorsing conspiracy theories to boost their careers. A devotee of prevarication and double-dealing, Molière would have made the most, in three acts, of stories like these. In some ways and in multiple plays, he already has. More than 350 years dead, he can seem effortlessly, wickedly contemporary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: CUNY Law School Graduates Turn Their Backs to Mayor Adams
description: As Mayor Eric Adams began speaking at the law school’s commencement service, many of the graduates, in their caps and gowns, turned away from him in a show of protest.
content: If Mayor Eric Adams needed a sign that his commencement speech to law students on Friday was not going to go well, the moment came even before he spoke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: To Meet Sky-High Expectations, Tears of the Kingdom Goes Vertical
description: The Legend of Zelda’s latest entry required the series producer Eiji Aonuma and the director Hidemaro Fujibayashi to optimize the location of floating islands and the thrill of skydiving.
content: When Breath of the Wild was released in 2017, it rescued The Legend of Zelda, a video game franchise growing stale because of a predictable gameplay loop of dungeons and fetch quests. By re-emphasizing freedom, the game allowed players to experiment with a dynamic physics system in ways that even its developers did not fully anticipate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Why the Anti-Trump Republican Primary Has Yet to Emerge
description: The former president’s current and potential rivals have failed to gain traction as the party seems to rally around him in the face of criticism.
content: Just a few months ago, the Republican presidential primary seemed as if it might include a frank and vigorous debate about the leadership and limitations of Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Fast Recipes That Feel Luxurious
description: Salmon takes a hot bath in infused olive oil, and a refreshing cucumber salad gets a lush lift from avocado.
content: Mother’s Day approaches, and whether you gather with loved ones or ignore it altogether (or, if you’re a mom, slink off to spend the day doing whatever you like, all by yourself — a thrilling thought), it never hurts to have something good to eat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, Edgar Sandoval and J. David Goodman
title: Migrants Struggle to Get Appointments on Border Protection App
description: The problems faced by migrants suggested that an important strategy for alleviating crowding at the border still faced challenges.
content: Among the tools the Biden administration is using to alleviate crowding at the U.S.-Mexico border is a new mobile app that migrants must use before entering the United States to secure an appointment with the Border Patrol to submit an asylum application.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: Rosie O’Donnell Lists Her Manhattan Penthouse (as Malibu Beckons?)
description: The duplex apartment on East 49th Street is on the market for $8.3 million, slightly above what the comedian and actor paid for it six years ago.
content: Rosie O’Donnell is bidding farewell to New York City, at least for the time being.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: The Pandemic Threat That Hasn’t Gone Away
description: Lab safety failures have been a continual danger, with too little being done.
content: In December 2014, two monkeys in outdoor cages at the Tulane National Primate Research Center, about 40 miles north of New Orleans, became ill with Burkholderia pseudomallei, a deadly bacteria in the federal government’s highest risk category, reserved for pathogens like smallpox, anthrax and Ebola. This is the category for which the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention sees “significant potential for mass casualties or severe effects.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller and Sapna Maheshwari
title: Ex-ByteDance Executive Accuses Company of ‘Lawlessness’
description: The former executive sued ByteDance, which owns TikTok, for wrongful termination and accused the company of lifting content from rivals and “supreme access” by the Chinese Communist Party.
content: A former executive at ByteDance, the Chinese company that owns TikTok, has accused the technology giant of a “culture of lawlessness,” including stealing content from rival platforms Snapchat and Instagram in its early years, and called the company a “useful propaganda tool for the Chinese Communist Party.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: Call It Postmodern Love
description: Joe Fay and Dan Garness first met in what is now the Burns House, designed by the postmodernist architect Charles Moore.
content: Joseph Bartlett Fay and Daniel Wayne Garness, fittingly, met face-to-face inside an architectural landmark — now known as the Burns House, designed by Charles Moore, the postmodernist architect, on a hillside in Santa Monica Canyon in California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar
title: What’s Your Favorite Video Game Ever?
description: Tell us about it, and what makes it great.
content: Do you love playing video games? Do you crave the freedom to explore open-world games like Minecraft or Batman: Arkham City? Are you a fan of classics like Tetris, Pac-Man or Donkey Kong? Do you prefer sports games like Tony Hawk’s skater series, Rocket League or FIFA games? Or puzzle games like the World of Goo or online chess?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: Migrants Deported to Mexico Face Criminals and Predatory Officials
description: Those made to leave the U.S. face gangs and a Mexican asylum system where cases linger for years.
content: As the United States begins imposing border rules making it more difficult for migrants to claim asylum, many will most likely face swift deportation to Mexico, where they will be vulnerable to criminal groups and corrupt officials, according to human rights groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Márquez
title: The Long and Violent History of Anti-Black Racism in the Latino Community
description: The gunman in Allen, Texas, wasn’t the first nonwhite proponent of white supremacy.
content: The gunman in last weekend’s massacre at an outlet mall in Allen, Texas — which left eight people dead and at least seven injured — wore a vest inscribed with the letters RWDS, short for Right Wing Death Squad, and had tattoos of a swastika and an SS lightning bolt insignia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Thomas Stacy, Master of the English Horn, Dies at 84
description: Through his decades with the New York Philharmonic and his busy touring schedule, he helped make an unfamiliar instrument much less so.
content: Thomas Stacy sometimes told the story of how, when he was a boy growing up in Arkansas, an Italian who had been dead for about 80 years changed his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla, Edgar Sandoval, Miriam Jordan and Simon Romero
title: In Migrant Camps, Anxiety and Relief: ‘It Was Worth It. We Are in America.’
description: Pandemic-era migration restrictions were lifted without a fresh spike in border crossings. Thousands of migrants now find themselves in a holding pattern.
content: SAN DIEGO — In the vast migrant camp that sprung up this week on a patch of U.S. soil between Tijuana and San Diego, a striking system of order has emerged, even as anxiety and uncertainty swell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht and Joe Orovic
title: Serbia Offers Amnesty for Illegal Firearms, and Thousands Are Collected
description: The unregistered weapons were handed over to the authorities as the government vows to disarm the country after two mass shootings.
content: The Serbian authorities have collected thousands of weapons in a sweeping campaign to reduce the number of firearms in the hands of civilians in the week after two mass shootings stunned the country, officials said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: A Taylor Swift Memoir? Not So Fast.
description: When rumors started swirling that the pop star was writing a book, Swifties were ready for it. But their hunt for Easter eggs led them to a different global phenomenon: BTS.
content: For Taylor Swift fans, the clues were everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: She Wrote a Blistering Satire About Publishing. The Publishing Industry Loves It.
description: In “Yellowface,” R.F. Kuang draws on her own experiences to tackle issues like cultural appropriation and representation. “I hate the feeling of being read just because somebody’s trying to tick off a diversity check box,” she says.
content: Everything about R.F. Kuang’s novel “Yellowface” feels engineered to make readers uncomfortable. There’s the title, which is awkward to say out loud, and the cover, which features a garish racial stereotype — cartoonish slanted eyes imposed on a block of yellow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan and Michael D. Shear
title: Border Is Calm as Crowds Cross and Biden Administration Fights Court Ruling
description: Despite the relative calm, the Biden administration faces court challenges that they say may undermine efforts to deal with record levels of border crossings.
content: The southern border of the United States was crowded with migrants on Friday, but not chaotic, following the lifting of Title 42 pandemic-era restrictions. Yet Biden administration officials lashed out at court challenges from the right and left that they said could undermine efforts to deal with record levels of border crossings in the days and weeks ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha C. White
title: Once an Evangelist for Airbnbs, She Now Crusades for Affordable Housing
description: Precious Price ditched her profitable business  of renting home stays to tourists to combat the mounting housing crisis.
content: “Making It Work” is a series is about small-business owners striving to endure hard times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Why P-22 Is Still Everywhere in Los Angeles
description: After his death, the mountain lion from Griffith Park was inescapable and celebrated in a museum exhibit as a “hero.”
content: Before P-22 died in December, I’ll admit I was only vaguely aware that there was a mountain lion living in Griffith Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. Faces ‘Significant Risk’ of Running Out of Cash in June, Budget Office Warns
description: A default would cause financial distress, economic disruptions and rapid increases in borrowing rates, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said.
content: The Congressional Budget Office said on Friday that there was a “significant risk” that the federal government could run out of cash sometime in the first two weeks of June, setting the United States up for a default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: F.D.A. Approves New Drug to Treat Hot Flashes
description: It is the first nonhormonal treatment for the menopause symptom.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved the first nonhormonal medication to treat hot flashes in menopausal women, offering a potential remedy for the symptoms of overheating of the upper body and sweating that can be disruptive to daily life for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Ian Black
title: Meet ‘Harold,’ a Dreamy Third Grader With a Lot on His Mind
description: In his odd and wonderful first novel, the deadpan comedian Steven Wright takes us inside the head of a boy who broods over love, time, God and piñatas.
content: Harold is a third grader with a rectangle in the middle of his head. Birds fly through this rectangle bearing thoughts. There are many birds and many, many thoughts for Harold to ponder. Some of the birds are real, like cardinals and parakeets, and some, like the “all white Leopard Whale bird that only existed in Sweden for 35 years starting in the early 1400s,”  not so much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Britain’s Economy Ekes Out Growth in First Quarter
description: The increase of 0.1 percent in the three months that ended in March, which was driven by construction and information services, matched the slow rise in the previous quarter.
content: The British economy grew 0.1 percent in the first three months of the year, from the previous quarter, the Office for National Statistics said on Friday. It matched the slow pace of growth in the last quarter of last year.

title: Kenji López-Alt’s Tips for Juicy, Crisp-Skinned Salmon? Add Salt and Wait.
description: Dry-brining fillets‌ works wonders, making cooking a breeze and yielding unforgettably succulent results.
content: The process of resting salted poultry, steaks or chops in the fridge overnight, known as “dry-brining” or “short-curing,” is a popular way to improve juiciness, tenderness, browning and searing. But why don’t we dry-brine fish — particularly salmon — more often?
source.name: The New York Times

description: A horticulturist, she discovered farming methods that increased yields of the fruit as its health benefits became widely understood and demand for it grew.
content: Bernadine Strik, a horticulture professor at Oregon State University whose innovative cultivation strategies shook up the American blueberry industry, died on April 14 at a hospital in Corvallis, Ore. She was 60.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Iran Releases 2 French Citizens From Detention
description: Benjamin Brière and Bernard Phelan had been accused of spying, which they denied. They had protested their captivity with hunger strikes, and their families had fought for their release.
content: Two French citizens detained by Iran were released on Friday on humanitarian grounds and made their way back to France, according to French and Iranian authorities.

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Can My New Boyfriend Stop My Ex From Visiting Our Dog?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether a former partner has the right to see a previously shared pet.
content: A year into our relationship, I adopted a dog with my now ex-partner. I’m a veterinarian, and we adopted a sick dog with a lot of recurrent medical needs. After two and a half years of dating, we broke up last May. Our breakup was amicable, and we agreed I would take the dog given that I’m better equipped to manage her health issues. (During the relationship, I was also the one that paid for all of her medical bills, food, etc.) We further agreed that he would most likely see her every now and then.

title: With Title 42’s End, Scenes of Anxiety, Weariness and Relief at the Border
description: Some people tried last-minute crossings overnight, but most of the border was quiet on Friday, while U.S. officials braced for the days ahead.
content: The expiration of Title 42, which authorized swift expulsions of many asylum seekers, was widely expected to unleash chaos in border cities like El Paso, where a respite destination, the Sacred Heart Church, was already overwhelmed with some 2,000 migrants this week.

description: Mark F. Pomerantz appeared for a deposition before the House Judiciary Committee but declined to answer many of the panel’s questions, citing privilege and the confidentiality of the prosecution.
content: Mark F. Pomerantz, a former prosecutor who once helped lead an investigation of Donald J. Trump, appeared on Friday before the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee for a deposition but declined to answer many of its questions about the prosecution of the former president on charges of falsifying business records.

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Hodding Carter III, Crusading Editor and Jimmy Carter Aide, Dies at 88
description: As a journalist in Mississippi, he championed civil rights. He later became the face of the U.S. government during the Iranian hostage crisis.
content: Hodding Carter III, a crusading Mississippi newspaperman who championed civil rights for Black Americans in the 1960s and who, as a Carter administration official, was the nation’s prime source of information on the Iranian hostage crisis in 1979 and 1980, died on Thursday in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pulitzer Winners
description: Hua Hsu, author of the memoir “Stay True,” and Hernan Diaz, author of the novel “Trust,” discuss their books and their reactions to winning the Pulitzer Prize.
content: The Pulitzer Prizes were announced on Monday, bestowing one of America’s most prestigious awards in journalism and the arts on writers across a range of categories. Among the winners were three authors who had also appeared on the Book Review’s list of the 10 Best Books of 2022: the New Yorker staff writer Hua Hsu, for his memoir “Stay True,” and two novelists who (in a first for the Pulitzers) shared the prize in fiction, Barbara Kingsolver for “Demon Copperhead” and Hernan Diaz for “Trust.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Turkey’s President Amassed Power. He Could Still Lose This Election.
description: Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, has tilted the political playing field in his favor over the past two decades, concentrating power in his own hands. Still, he faces a stiff challenge in Sunday’s election.
content: ISTANBUL, Turkey — As President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey approaches the toughest election of his career on Sunday, he has marshaled many of the resources of the state to tilt the playing field to his advantage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Taking Photos to Change the Way We See the Bronx
description: “Everyday Bronx” is an online archive showing the vitality and beauty of a borough that is often overlooked or disparaged.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at the Bronx, as seen in photographs by people who live there. We’ll also find out why E. Jean Carroll’s lawyer says Carroll is considering another lawsuit against Donald Trump.

title: Inquiry Into Senator Menendez Broadens With New Subpoena
description: Prosecutors have asked Nicholas Sacco, a New Jersey senator and mayor, for correspondence related to a stalled bill and records linked to a halal enterprise.
content: Federal investigators leading an inquiry into Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, the powerful Democratic chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, subpoenaed records this week from at least one longtime New Jersey mayor and state senator, Nicholas Sacco, several officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Garret Graves, Republicans’ ‘Assistant Coach,’ Sees Hope in Debt Limit Talks
description: The Louisiana congressman, who acts as a consigliere to Speaker Kevin McCarthy, says four areas of potential compromise have emerged.
content: Representative Garret Graves, Republican of Louisiana, wasn’t elected to any House leadership position and doesn’t serve as a powerful committee chairman. But as a consigliere to Speaker Kevin McCarthy — who has described Mr. Graves as the G.O.P. “assistant coach” — he has become a central player on every big legislative push in the House.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Dolly Parton Goes Arena Rock, and 9 More New Songs

content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: What’s the Deal With Adulthood? 25 Years Later, ‘Seinfeld’ Feels Revelatory.
description: The show about nothing ended in May 1998. But in an era when priorities are being re-evaluated, the sitcom has taken on new relevance.
content: Early in the pandemic, I developed a strange habit. Every night, I’d slip my phone under my pillow and listen to an episode (or six) of “Seinfeld” through a few inches of poly-fill stuffing. Though for anyone who knows me, that inclination probably tracks.

description: If current forecasts hold, the storm could be the strongest and most dangerous since 2010 to hit the area, which is the site of many refugee camps.
content: A storm forecast to be the strongest to hit Myanmar in more than a decade is expected to make landfall near the Bangladesh border on Sunday, raising the prospect of a major humanitarian disaster.

title: New York Theater Workshop Announces New Artistic Director’s First Season
description: The Off Broadway nonprofit will embrace risk, said Patricia McGregor, its leader, favoring fresh over established works.
content: For New York Theater Workshop’s first season programmed after the departure of its longtime artistic director, the Off Broadway fixture plans to produce an intergenerational saga centered on a Black family in Illinois, a lesbian farce set on a naval base, a story about a mysterious album of Nazi-era photographs, and a play with an unusual star: a Microsoft text-to-speech tool.

content: It was one of the more surreal contract negotiations in N.F.L. history. At the start of training camp in July 1971, Joe Kapp, the New England Patriots’ star quarterback, was locked in an office with Upton Bell, the team’s new general manager, and Billy Sullivan, its principal owner.

title: The Batters Have No Idea What’s Coming Next
description: Shane McClanahan of the Tampa Bay Rays started last season’s All-Star Game and is 7-0. His mastery of four elite pitches can make things seem “impossible.”
